>>18936140
1) Take any root vegetable and slice it thin. (Of course give yourself a firm base by slicing in half first) (Most are fine to just scrub with a brush but leave unpeeled -- plenty of flavor and nutrients, and you're not serving at a restaurant.)
2) Pat slices relatively dry with paper or cloth. If the veg has a lot of moisture, you can draw it out with some salt or in the microwave at low heat, but I've never found it necessary.
3) brush with oil of choice (or toss in it if particularly porous, like lotus root), season, then put it in a medium-hot pan. Alternatively, bake the fuckers. With an online recipe remember these are thin as fuck, so you need to cook slower at lower heat or they will burn.
4) Give them a few minutes til they're lightly brown, then flip them, then transfer them to a rack or just right on a plate. There's no more oil in these chips than you would use in an air fryer, so there's no need for a drain step, and they're so thin that they're cool quick enough just fine directly on a plate -- thus you should eat them pretty soon after cooking if you want them hot and chewy.
4 alt.) Alternatively, go *really* low and slow in the oven until they are mostly dried out, and brittle, more like potato crisps.

Again, pretty much any root veg works for this. As part of testing out a root veg I haven't tried before, I usually make a small batch of these, among other things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18942754
Curry is a great one pot meal, coupled with microwave rice or naan and you are good for the week. Stores in jars perfectly, just nuke rice and curry and done.

Chili mac is a good one to make: both meat and carbs to keep you going. Also keeps in jars and is nukable. Straight chili also works.

Stews would also be a portable solution for when you get tired of the above. You can also do a ragu (meat or stock version) and premix with pasta to have jarred ready to heat meals. Couple with some grocery bread for the road.

Strogenoff also keeps reasonably well.

You can also do rice stir fry type meals and stick them in the bigger food prep containers if you want less calories.

Plus you can always carry some frozen items to mix it up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18938087
Food is a complex market in that there are multiple different sources as well as different suppliers of the same nutrients. So protein sources like eggs compete not just between suppliers, but also against beans, chicken, pork, beef, etc.

If your unit costs gets too high, people can swap to alternate protein sources. Additionally, high prices allow competitors to enter the market and undercut you, especially if they deliver similar quality. Keep in mind that food SPOILS, so you can't just sit on the eggs for months and sell them when demand ticks up later. Food made now needs to be processed and sold with a quick turnaround. So that means if you overproduce, you literally lose money.

This is why you get price reduction on food items where you would not see it for something inedible and shelf stable, like a battery for example. That battery is good for years, and there are only 2-3 makers for batteries. So you can "collude" a little bit to ensure prices stay level, and no one can really make batteries without massive investment in a factory. Good luck doing that with food where suppliers literally span countries and nations, and every Tom, Dick, and Harry with land and chickens can get in on your market.

>>18942584
What you're proposing will lead to shortages. There are many examples of this in the US, such as the gas shortages in the 70s, and shortages of just about everything in the lead up and aftermath of hurricanes.

The fact of the matter is that "price gouging" doesn't exist -- prices should (and do) communicate scarcity. If someone is offering something at a price you do not want to pay, then you're not obligated to purchase it.

I was nearly stranded a few years ago when evacuating my home due to an incoming hurricane, and couldn't hardly find gas anywhere. Every gas station I stopped at was out of gas to sell. I would have paid $20+ dollars a gallon to refuel, but no one had any to sell until I just lucked into stumbling upon a station that had some to sell. Florida has anti-gouging laws that caused this problem. If the price of gasoline was allowed to rise appropriately (that is to "price gouging" levels), then that would have signaled to gasoline suppliers that there was a high demand and low supply of gasoline in my area and therefore an opportunity to make a significant profit. Beyond that though, the high prices signal that it is scarce to other potential buyers and would have priced out those buyers that were buying fuel "just in case". So, in this case, "price gouging" would have stimulated suppliers to direct supply where it is in high demand, and communicate to people which did not need fuel to not buy it leading to no shortage or less of one.

>>18943897
>You know what it costs to deliver supplies to a disaster zone?
Fuel and a pair of balls. People who want things a lot will pay a high price; people who don't want things a lot will pay a low price or not buy it at all. Price gouging is arbitrage in action - price discovery in action. When gouging (raising prices in accordance with increased demand) is outlawed we see shortages, because when a gallon of gas in a hurricane is worth the same as a gallon of gas in Milwaukee people stop delivering to the hurricane. They shrug and say "damn, sucks to be those guys". Call it evil if you want but price gouging gets fuel, food and clean water to disaster zones while price controls make shortages. If it wasn't worth what gougers are selling it for people wouldn't buy it. You say "oh but I need it", and yeah, that's why it's worth so much. Supply and demand.

>>18944121
I'll skip the potatos cause I legit don't have a proper technique for them since they apparently depend too much of the type of potato. But I sugest you do them yourself since fries are a gift of the gods.

Here's how you fry the whole thing
. add enough olive or sunflower oil to fully cover the egg whites to the pan, wait till the pan is relatively hot not too much, just has enough temperature
. then add chorizo slices, like half the small finger thick, add like 5 per person, more if you want
. then when the choirzo is on point set it apart in the serving plate
. then add the egg
. sprinkle the hot oil over the yolk until it turns pink-ish full, then focus on the egg whites and sprinkle oil over the uncooked parts
. when that is done retire the egg, scatter some salt over the egg yolk and you're ready to go
. . the whole proccess should be relatively quick like 2 minutes or so

Enjoy anon

It depends on the oil he used, the temp he was using to polymerize, and how thick of a layer of oil he was using, if it was a sufficiently thin layer, at the proper temp, allowed to cool down between coats, etc. It COULD be pretty decently strong.

>>18937646
>It's double the price but not double the size. So no, it doesn't really make sense.
On the Lodge website, the 12" is $30, and the 13.25" is $50. Their most common model is the $10.25", which is regularly $24 and currently marked down to $20. One of the reasons cast iron, in general, is not popular is due to the weight. We can see that the 12", at 7.89 lbs, is 47% heavier than the 10.25" (5.35 lbs), and the 13.25", at 10.5 lbs, is 100% heavier than the 10.25" skillet. So based on weight, there is TWICE the iron in the 13.25 inch skillet as in the 10.25 inch skillet--you might have had some inkling of this if you understood the difference between diameter and area of a circle.

Based on material alone, the regular price of the 10.25" being half of the 13.25" makes sense. However, you'd be stupid if you thought that was the only factor. Because the 10.25" is more popular, more stores are going to order them reliably. Lodge can make more of them, without worrying if they will sell and receive a return on their investment. It's the one model that they know they won't have leftover stock at the end of the year; therefore, they can afford to sell them with thinner margins. Hence the $20 price right now.

So basically, you're a complete idiot and you should feel bad about it.

>>18942489
basically you can do anything with them other than washing them in a dish washer. Dish soap will not harm your seasoning, the idea you can't use soap on your cast iron was back when it was made with Lye. Rough or smooth doesn't really matter outside of aesthetics, really the only thing that matters on the seasoning is using an oil or fat with a high smoke point if you want to make reverse sear meme steaks where you need to get the skillet to 500 degrees.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Also, if your'e using your cast iron pan daily (or every other or so day), there is no need to be paranoid and to wash them after every use.
Just leave the food particles and seasoning on it and put it away inside of the oven, or on top of the stove, (but don't put lid on it), let the air dry the stuff out, and just use it when you're ready.

I used to wipe them out with a paper towel, (but almost never used water to wash it with).
But for the last few years I have 8 inch cast iron pan that I use it twice a day, (morning and evening), and I don't even wipe it anymore.
Just scraping the food with a spoon, and I'm leaving it on top of the stove, (again, no lid on it).

BTW,
go to used stuff store and buy size matching clear glass lids from those glass pots.
They work great on cast iron pans.
Of course if you live in a shithole where you have swarms of flies flying like chinese balloons in your kitchen then you can not leave it on top of the stove.
Just put the fucker inside of the stove.

I know, some primitive paranoid faggottss will become suicidal after reading this, but those who have brains try it.
Nothing fucking bad will happen to it, no need to be cleaning freak all the time.
I'm doing this for like almost 10 years now, it's just small particles of dried food and spices.

>>18942369
>expensive enameled shit,
BTW,
for this uneducated pleb.
Cast iron enamelled pans are preferable if you are concerned with too much iron "leaking" into your food, especially if you are preparing acid forming foods, like tomatoes, etc.
Of course frying eggs on enamelled pans is not as easy as is on "bare" cast iron.
Eggs, (and some other foods), will stick to enamelled surfaces.
Eggs will just slide right off from the "bare" cast iron surface pan.
But as always, main thing is to make sure that you pre-heat your pans before you put food into them, regardless what material they are made of.

I like using enamelled cast iron pans for stewing veggies or meat.
They keep heat for so long that when the food is 50% or 75% done, I just turn the heat off and let it cook on till is done.
Have another one, enamelled, 10" x 3 " deep.
The one in the picture is 10" x 2" deep.
Put glass lid on it and you're set.

I like you OP, and your poverty recipe can be useful to many. Let me share the jewel of my family, concerning eggs.
. when you fry the eggs, you grabb a tea spoon and sprinkle hot oil over the yolk, untill it turns full pink, and the egg whites are completely done. By that point the egg is ready.
And now the best part, you first fry in the same oil good quality chorizo until it changes color, small to medium slices of it. Similar to fried eggs and bacon, but for me, better. Once everything is done you scatter some salt over the pink yolks and you're ready to go. Enjoy.

>>18940730
That's definitely too long unless it's sitting in the fridge. At room temperature yeast will eat most of what it can and then die around 12-14 hours later. Though too much yeast is also a potential problem, especially if it's the instant dry stuff.
Also, if you're doing a single long fermentation, you'll need to fold ("punch") the dough a few times through, which will redistribute the yeast and its food, release some of that gas which is actually toxic to the yeast, and relax your gluten.

>>18941977
I used 6 C flour (plus some depending on what the dough wants)
1-2 tsp. salt(fine)
made well after mixing dry with a fork then added:
1 ¾C water + ½C half and half heated to 115°
2 tsp. raw sugar
1 heaping tsp. yeast from the jar
and 6Tbsp melted butter (I used a whole stick, the remaining went into buttering the pans.
kneaded until smooth,
let rise until doubled,
Whacked the bubbles outta the dough and rolled it into the standard loaf shape for the pan
(Two folds, then fold in the ends with a pinch)
slit the tops 3x then brushed with last of the butter,
375°F oven, middle shelf for 26 mins.

I make the baugette style too and sometimes the freeform bowl dump kind.

My basic pidser dough that makes 2 large pidzers is just 4 cups flour, 1 tsp. salt, 1½ Cup water, teaspoon yeast, and 3 Tblsp. Olive oil.

There isn't any food I can think of. There are lots of Italian, Thai, Viet, Lebanese and Korean dishes which are vegetarian, delicious and exciting. Until you have to eat them all the time - then you become desperate.

Caponata for instance is fantastic, 3-5 times a year, in summer. But it gets boring real quick and even turns to shit when you add pasta, rice, curry powder, anchovy w/e. Same goes for tabbouleh, pho, kimchi, borsjt, Mexican, pumpkin, whatever the next Flavour Of The Month (FOTM) is.

The only exceptions are spring veg (hop shoots, asparagus, may cauliflower, spring onions, baby carrots, first radishes, bear garlic) and mushroom dishes.

>>18930663
I got one of those Zojirushi Japanese rice cookers and it's become one of my favorite kitchen items.

There's the obvious benefits:
Rice is always cooked perfect, better than I do in a pot, it's easier, I can't mess it up, and the cleanup is easier.

But the really big one that you don't realize until you have one is that it's fire and forget. Before you start cooking you load it up and start it and you never have to worry about the rice again until you need it. This thing cooks the rice perfect by itself and then can keep it warm and at perfect consistency for over 12 fucking hours. When you need the rice you just open it up and scoop it out.

Also it plays twinkle twinkle little star to let me know when the rice is done. (Japan you silly.)

posts.com:
Pretty bad. Varies a lot, actually. Some prisons have farms, and they sometimes eat OK, if the food isn't intended for sale to the public. I've been in small county jails with no kitchen facilities that serve frozen tv dinners 3x per day. Varies wildly. From nutriloaf level forms of culinary punishment to decent cafeteria care, but generally it's pretty fucking bad. Expired ingredients, weevil infestations, poor sanitary conditionss and such are not uncommon.

That being said, I spent a month in juvenile as a kid, and I ate better than I ever did at home, though that's probably more a reflection on my mother than the quality of food served by the state.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I've went to jail a couple of times over a decade ago, never prison, and my longest "stint" was 4 days (former drug addict here, nothing crazy.) Also it was a comfy wipipo jail in the suburbs, not some inner city rape fest thank God. It all depends on your perspectives.

I'll put it like this. If you were given the choice between jail food and outside food, of course you'd choose outside food 8 days out of the week. Jail food sucked man, the portions are tiny, the food is underseasoned and all they give you are some tiny salt and pepper packets that are about the size of your thumb nail. Crispy things are soft, soft things are rock hard, hot things are cold and cold things are suspiciously warm. I mean what are you expecting, it's fucking jail, not a 5 star resort.

That being said, when you've been in jail for 16 hours and it's become abundantly clear that you're not getting out any time soon, a plate of lukewarm goyslop doesn't sound too bad. I got "lucky" during one of my trips to jail and I got to eat one of the bi-monthly hot breakfasts (normally it's cereal). Two tiny sausage patties, two tiny pancakes, a tiny syrup packet and no butter, one single limp dick slice of bacon and a fruit cup. Sounds like garbage to you. But for someone who hadn't eaten all day because I got arrested in the middle of the night, it was actually a pretty good meal. Oh yeah, and an acceptable side dish in jail is a half a slice of disgusting wheat bread. I got that shit during every single meal. It was gross.

1/2

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18937504
Commissary isn't much better, but again it can be serviceable if you're really hungry/looking for taste of home. I only had a commissary card one time during my few visits, and one look at the menu told me it was a total rip off. Things that should be paltry like bags of chips, pickles, hot sauce, tuna, and ramen were like 5x their outside price. Headphones and calling cards were like 10x a reasonable outside price. Just another way to extract money from people in jail.

I did try jail cuisine one single time, but it was wasted on me. I was detoxing/withdrawing from drugs when one of the guys in my block who coincidentally went to the same college I did cooked up some kind of jail house burrito. I remember him breaking up some bags of ramen and cheetos into a powder and mixing it with nacho cheese and hot sauce and chopped up pepperoni sticks. Since I was dope sick at the time, all I needed as a wiff of that bullshit and it was enough to make me gag, and it wasn't much better going down either. I only ate a few bites of my burrito before throwing it out. Looking back, that was such a dick move. That guy didn't have to spend his hard earned jail money and waste his time crafting a jail burrito for me, but he did, and I didn't even have the curtosey to finish it. Kinda a weird thing to think about when it comes to jail but it's one of the more interesting things that happened to me in there. Otherwise we mostly watched TV and talked shit.

The first meal after you're released does empirically taste better than it would otherwise though. A fucking baconator and spicy nuggets from Wendy's never tasted so good brehs. It tasted like freedom.

Luckliy I haven't been back there in many years, but I can't assume it's gotten any better.

So I've never been to prison, but when I was a teenager my parents made me do one of those "scared straight" things where I had to go on a tour of the county jail, and eat the food.

It tastes... neutral. It's not disgusting inedible slop like you see on movies, it's just really bland. They gave us a ham and cheese sandwich, a carton of milk, and the smallest apple you've ever seen. Apparently this was what the inmates ate most days. It's just ground up beans and shit all clumped together, really nasty shit. But being the autistic chad I was, I ate all of it and asked for more solely to spite the guards.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18943904
There's no physical money in jail. Every prisoner has a bank account, the most common way that prisoners get money in their account is that they work, from sweeping floors to working in the kitchen, all jails have internal jobs that employ prisoners helping with the day to day running of the facility. The pay is shit but it's better than nothing and it's usually used to buy some decent grub that you cook for yourself. Some jails have other employment opportunities where you can work outside jobs, usually minimum security offenders get this.
Secondly money can be deposited into a prisoners bank account from anyone on the outside just like any old bank account, usually by family members. Jailhouse drug dealers commonly exploit this by getting other inmates to wire money to them through family or friends on the outside for exchange for drugs that they have had smuggled in.

When I was an inmate I worked in the prison chapel keeping the place clean and helping out the prison chaplain and was payed around 60 bucks a week for about 2 hours work. Enough to supply me with three days worth of drugs

>>18919002
Reminder that 95% of scotch distilleries are owned by multi-national corporations, import barley from countries overseas such as Turkey and Egypt, do the malting offsite, buy peat from other regions of Britain, use lab-created yeast for their mash, use barrels made from American or Spanish wood, and add caramel coloring to the final product.

The only thing authentic about any particular region or scotch distillery is the water or copper stills, both of which could hardly be said to contribute any unique flavor profile to the scotch over any other distillery.

The only thing that gives a scotch an authentically unique flavor profile that is not imported from elsewhere is the process by which the components are put together, i.e. smoked peat, grain ratios, etc. This is a process, which has nothing to do with utilizing the resources of the terroir.

All of this wouldn't be so bad if it wasn't for the over-insistence that each distillery possesses a unique terroir. French wine for example has much stricter requirements for the definition of something like Champagne. If the grapes don't come from Champagne, it is not Champagne.

You are buying a good that is being sold to you as a goodgoy lifestyle product, like a bottle of Armani cologne. There is nothing uniquely Scottish to a bottle of scotch whisky in 2023. It is a globohomo product that is purposefully aimed toward the same soijaks who buy Bespoke Post and Beard Oil and wax philosophic dilletantism about the "delicious" and "complex" smokey peat flavor of Islay malts while looking down their noses at Speyside drinkers, pretending that Don Draper is "literally me" not knowing they're all part of the same retarded, consoomerist goycattle, drinking the epitome of a fake product.

Scotch drinkers are the worst.

>half of this is blatantly wrong
I would absolutely love for you to try to disprove anything I said. Let's take a look at 95% of the scotches reposted in /wsg/ and see who their owners are, shall we?

LVMH (French):
Ardbeg, Glenmorangie

Diageo (English):
Johnnier Walker, Talisker, Lagavulin, Caol Ila

Beam Suntory (Japan):
Laphroaig, Ardmore, Auchentoshan, Bowmore

Pernod Ricard (France):
Aberlour, Strathclyde, Glenlivet, Scapa, Lomond, Chivas

Remy Cointreau (France):
Bruichladdich, Octomore, Port Charlotte

Distell (Africa):
Bunnahabhain
Glenblair

Emperador (Phillipines [lol]):
Dalmore, Jura

That enough for you, faggot? Wow, sure are a lot of authentically, wholly-owned Scottish companies in that list, huh? And you really believe international mega-corporations aren't going to cut corners to fulfill the obligation to their shareholders?

The majority of barley is imported through Port Ellen (owned by Diageo), 80-90% of which is foreign import. It is germinated and malted onsite at Port Ellen. As for the barrels, check the websites of any scotch brands and find me a single one not made with American, Spanish or French oak, I dare you. Caramel coloring is not only a reality of scotch production but actually *sanctioned* by the British government - check the regulations yourself. That authentic peat flavor you bloviate about endlessly can comes from Aberdeenshire - the literal other side of the country from Islay. Considering the distribution of peat worldwide, it would be of no surprise to me if this was imported from Eastern Europe as well.

So that whittles down the contribution of individual distilleries to their copper stills, their water and their process.

Please, enlighten me, what have I said that is *blatantly wrong*? That Champagne is not made in Champagne? Or that multi-billion dollar corporations aren't going to dump a fortune into marketing to losers like you?

Global ownership isn't relevant.
The corners aren't particularly cut because there are non foreign owned distilleries to compete against (if anything the big multi nationals are competing more heavily on price and value which is good for the consumer).
There is a distinct taste to the peat sourced through Port Ellen, we don't really care about it's origin.
Used American Oak is the hallmark of scotch whisky. Everyone is expecting this and it's basically required.
Caramel colouring is overrated as a flaw. It doesn't really effect flavour.
Stills are hugely relevant.
Marketing isn't. We're all whisky nerd here, so cut the bullshit and taste some whisky. Scotch isn't bad because you're angry about politics or terroir.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Nose: Burned chicken in gravy, wood smoke, overheating electronics, marmite and malt out of the bottle, upon first uncorking. Hints of anise and candy-apple subsequently appear. In the glass, the apple and burning electrical equipment dominate, with new notes of hospital disinfectant and wood glue.
>Taste: Wood smoke, creamy caramel, oak, burned chicken without gravy, a hint of peach, citrus, malt and apple. Almost no burn going down at all.
>Finish: More smoke, tobacco, and wood glue.
>Verdict: My favorite scotch and favorite alcoholic drink of any kind. I was expecting Laphroaig 10 to be a peat-dominant, savory, malty scotch before trying it, but in fact it is a whole trifecta, straddling all of the three major flavor profile categories of scotch - it manages to have wonderful rich confectionery and fruit notes, better than those found in most other whiskies I've had, in addition to all the peated flavors. My dream scotch would be a dry, earthy dram like Dewar's White Label but with much more complexity, strength and smoke in it, and whilst this did not end up fitting that bill, it is an absolutely excellent whisky.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18944032
>Nose: Alcohol, and not the good kind. Primarily some kind of paint stripper, maybe with a dead rat left in it for good measure. On the second pass, after the tears had cleared from my eyes, I get desinfectant, weed killer and a hint of mustard gas. Amazing, how can something be this much of a punch to the nose with only 40% abv?
>Palate: What the....? As a lifelong atheist, Im not one to resort to religious ejaculations, but I'll make an exception in this case: Jesus F'ing Chirst what is this? My tongue is trying to flee down the back of my throat, the roof of my mouth is on fire, and my lips are considering a change in career. This tastes like somehting the kids came up with while playing with their chemistry kits. Words escape me, and after a while, the first to come back are "cadaverous", "vile", "rotting", "toxic".
>Finish: Oh, if only it were finished, but of course, it's long, monumentally long, just to drag out the torture. I remember getting a nasty sunburn as a kid, and if that had been on the inside of my mouth, I'm sure that's how it would taste and feel. That'll teach you to not use sunscreen - I'd honestly prefer a mouth full of sunscreen right now. Gasoline fumes rising from my esophagus, with a sidenote of that brown juice that drips out of the bottom of a compost heap. Please stop.
>Overall: Do people actually drink and enjoy this stuff? Or is it just some elaborate joke to take the piss out of newbs like me? I'll be heading back to the Highlands as far as whisky is concerned, and I'll think long and hard before considering another trip to Islay.

>>18940012
(Sockeye) salmon nigiri with wasabi only. I hate seeing retarded almost-weebs mixing wasabi into their soy sauce, or even just using soy sauce at all DESU. Also funny to see them putting it on the rice instead of the fish.

That's my go-to, but I also love hamachi (though it's usually expensive), ebi, and toro. Negitoro is my favorite maki, and it's usually what I order first to judge the quality of the restaurant I'm at. I also occasionally indulge in the new age shit like volcano rolls and dynamite rolls. I think crushed tempura batter is a great addition to sushi if you're looking for something tasty but not super classic. Better yet, aburi is fantastic as it adds depth, so long as the chef is careful to not cook the meat and only torch the outside. Aburi and beef tartare are definitely the things to order from a higher dollar Japanese/French fusion place (several in Vancouver and probably elsewhere). Pretty fantastic

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18942559
Longjing grown in the official designated region starts at around $800lb maybe a bit more, and goes up to eye wateringly high prices. The tea probably isn't worth it, ive had good longjing style teas that were 16¢ per gram or so. The main reason it's so expensive is that it is a very popular and prestigious gift that is valued highly in Chinese gifting culture where they consider the high price to be a positive thing to show how valuable their gift is. Unfortunately lots of the very high end of Chinese teas are subject to this gifting culture price inflation so the prices won't necessarily reflect their value as a tea drinking experience. There are also some teas like silver needle white tea where the grading and value is based totally on the appearance and size of the buds and the actual taste of the tea falls fairly low on the the list of qualities the tea is priced and judged for. That's why it's important to have a decent understanding of Chinese teas before you start throwing money around in the upper price categories of tea. As with most luxury commodities expensive doesn't always = better.

That video was the most ignorant shit I've seen in some time. It's a great example of someone *just beginning* to take the plunge on the Dunning-Kruger curve regarding medicine. Every one of his arguments is based on a single rat study here, an in vitro study there -- no notice of how irrelevant those are (i.e., completely) to giving actual practical medical advice to humans (which requires a progression of studies, using the former as only a starting point to guide hypotheses, that look at how humans are actually affected at multiple scales). And yet in my heart I was always hoping that all the cancer research over the decades had finally taught the world to not flip out over rat studies anymore.

In real reviews by actual professionals of all the actual research on topics like the ones in that video, such as whether there is some problem lurking in muh sneed oils, there has been found no evidence. Not "weak evidence" or 'minor significance" -- no evidence, not significant. That doesn't mean something can never come up in the future, but it does mean there's no reason to suspect anything now (and why is that? because they looked at all the possible things that could come up in the near future in current research.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
They are unhealthy because they contain large amounts of unstable fatty acids that can break down into toxins (you’ll see them referenced as PUFAs or polyunsaturated fatty acids). PUFA should not represent more than 10% of our diet because of this instability, and probably 4-5% would be better since that’s more in alignment with our historical intake.

PLUS–these oils should not be heated!

Because factory refining involves high heat, bottles of the Hateful 8 seed oils contain toxic compounds. And because foods cooked with seed oils contain even higher levels of toxins.

Americans now get 80 percent of their fat calories from seed oils because they are an ingredient in most processed foods. This translates to about 15-30% of calories from PUFA, which is historically unprecedented. And way, way too much.

Saturated fats (SFA) and monounsaturated fats (MUFA) are both pretty happy from an energetic perspective and won’t easily surrender any of their electrons to oxygen. But polyunsaturated fats (PUFA) are different. A free radical induced process called autoxidation leads them to become lipid peroxides, dangerous free radicals that can do damage to surrounding proteins and DNA. This is one of the reasons vegetable oils are high in vitamin E, an antioxidant. Antioxidants are “electron donors” and they step in to quickly give an electron to any superoxide molecules that come sniffing around to try to snatch an electron away from PUFA, thus stopping the PUFA from becoming oxidized.

Nonetheless, the threat of PUFA becoming oxidized is always there and PUFA oxidation is undoubtedly a bad thing. Which is why animals don’t make PUFA.

>>18940492
They don't define "ultra-processed" anywhere in the abstract because, as should be obvious, it's a term of art that's already defined (but not very precisely) in the literature. See https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6389637/
By any of their definitions based on Chick Fil-A's ingredients it would fall under "ultra-processed" since it includes "food substances not used in culinary preparations, in particular, flavors, colors, sweeteners, emulsifiers, and other additives". These definitions are made so broad and simplified that it doesn't really matter if the emulsifier or coloring is "natural" or not, just that its usage is not typical of a home-cooked group 1 preparation. Broad rough messy categories like these are not uncommon in research -- they make sifting through shitloads of messy data easier. Since all analysis is statistical, the edge cases of misclassification should be evened out or unimportant.

Which brings us to the point of the paper -- it's not saying that a *specific* set of ultra-processed foods are correlated (or by mounting evidence causal) with this decline, or that *all* ultra-processed foods are correlated with this decline, but rather that on average, over the diet that is eaten of the weighted sampling of 1st-world participants that they studied, the cognitive decline is associated (probably causally) with consumption of foods the bulk of which are in the ultra-processed category.

To figure out if Chick Fil-A specifically is one of those foods, that's actually much easier, since you can just study the consumption of Chick Fil-A or its specific ingredients in isolation. Since so many people eat Chick Fil-A regularly, or its ingredients in very similar combinations, this would be a relatively easy cross-sectional survey to set up (and probably already has been, multiple times)

The dough in question is the following:

450 g bread flour

it's not called like this in the netherlands. we just call it a "gietijzeren pan" which translates to "cast iron pan" but dutch technology is used to create them. this is the explanation.

In the seventeenth century, molds for making cast iron objects were developed in the Netherlands using a special sand mixture. The Englishman Abraham Darby became acquainted with this unknown technique in the Netherlands and introduced it to England. After much experimentation, he succeeded in making rock-solid cast iron pans. Because of the Dutch technique, these pans subsequently became known as Dutch Ovens. A name that has always remained.

Le Creuset Dutch Ovens are the superior choice of material over Staub Dutch Ovens. They last for a long time and are far more reliable, so you don't have to worry about needing to buy a new one any time soon. The enameled interior prevents food from sticking, making it easier to clean and more versatile. Le Creuset Dutch Ovens also have wide, easy-grip handles and you can use them on both gas and electric stoves, making them all-around great kitchen tools. All in all, they are the superior choice when it comes to Dutch Ovens.

posts.com:
>>18928639
I like an actual 4qt. I don't often need the size of a 5-6qt, and 3qt is indeed too small for the effort of making something that is literally only 1-2 servings.

Chili and any soup with beans really does well in it. This could be lentils or pasta faioli. It could be some a big pot of greens, a simple base of bacon and onions lining the bottom of the freshly rinsed mustards or collards. No sticking and no burning if you lose a moment of time in your busy cooking night. Creamy soups do better, like a potato soup, or a cheesy broccoli. I like to make a quick corn chowder, or a nearly quick pozole, and the hominy that sinks to the bottom stays unstuck.

Of course you will need a nice wooden spoon or silicone spoonula and a nice soft ladle to keep the ceramic lining nice. I love my staub silicone coated twin hardwood which is really a coated "spurtle" which is very versatile.

>>18939289
Pho is hard to compare to ramen, because ramen does not have a beef broth. It is either pork or miso based usually.

On the surface, yes, both are a bone broth with noodles and meat, ramen usually throwing in extra shit for giggles (like corn or bamboo shoots).

Personally, pho is cleaner tasting. It doesn't have the oils that ramen does and it just feels better for lunch. Ramen is always a bit greasy due to the extra oil they put in it. Ramen definitely wins the variety award for all the various toppings and extras you get though: eggs, bamboo shoots, corn, etc. The pork is definitely better than pho beef, because the pork is marinated and so, so good. Same with the marinated egg. Just a fantastic experience.

At the end of the day, pho is the best beef soup and ramen is the best pork soup. They each are heavy hitters of their respective corners.

>>18939734
>It doesn't have the oils that ramen does and it just feels better for lunch.
>The pork is definitely better than pho beef, because the pork is marinated and so, so good.
>Same with the marinated egg.
3 strikes, you are fucking OUT
First, your broth is, quite literally, shit. We pour flavoured tallow (the layer that we skimmed after floating to the top of the broth during long simmer) on top of our bowls. It shines with the layer of the rich fat. My lips will chafe and feel sticky after eating my Pho. And it's completely wrong if they weren't.
Second, properly cooked brisket for Pho, btfo any Ramen Cha Siu, this is from my personal experience with top-tier Pho (my mom's) and top-tier Ramen (top-rated Ramen shops ran by Japanese, both non-chain and chain). This point is closely linked to the first point, because a good broth will enhance the brisket as well. Brisket, cooked properly will be tender, yet springy. Something that Ramen Cha Siu will never achieve. You will have to use another pork cut for that.
Third, again, closely linked to the 1st point, you have never slurped a proper high-quality egg yolk from an indigenous egg, slightly cooked and warmed in a hot bowl of Pho, along with a spoonful of that quality broth. Ramen egg (or ajitsuke tamago) is also my favourite, but when faced with a properly served Pho egg, it simply can not compete.
The problem is that, most Pho restaurants here blow. Fucking disgrace.

>>18943605
The message of the painting was that everyone has an equally respected voice in democracy regardless of class/where you stand in society; even the seemingly lower class blue-collared people (juxtaposed against older men in suits).

The whole thing about "he can still speak even if he alone disagrees" is just your personal interpretation, and mostly a modern interpretation of the "Freedom of Speech" painting, because Freedom of Speech in the current age now means saying something politically incorrect against the mainstream's disapproval. Back when the painting was made, freedom of speech was a celebrated concept and an integral part of society and democracy, while many people in the modern age see it as an act of rebellion against society

>>18938182
For pasta I use 2 eggs per 1 cup of dough, makes me 3 portions, which really can feed 2 people, my op is one portion. Sometimes I do 2 cups and use 4 eggs for 6 portions, I've never bothered with more because 6 portions means I'm eating pasta all week.

To form, make a mound of flour, then starting from the center, create a well, have fingers together pointing down in like a wedge, spiral outwards to create basically a bowl of flour. Make sure walls are high and not to thin as you will break your eggs into this flour bowl.
Beat the eggs into an even consistency, and slowly incorporate flour, taking bits from the walls evenly, once egg flour mixture is becoming thick, use a dough scrapper to fold in the walls a cut into the thickened eggs. Do this for all of the walks and it should become a shaggy dough.
Begin to fold the dough, draw one part away and fold back on itself, this is to incorporate air into the dough, do this until the dough has fully come together, it should be a yellow color at this point, knead until smooth and portion

Whichever pasta you want them make, roll the portioned dough balls pretty much paper thin, it will double in size after boiling so keep that in mind. If you fold up your dough to cut ribbons like I did, be sure to lightly flour both sides to prevent it from mushing together. Flour the knife too to keep it from sticking.

>>18941866
For pasta dough?

2 cups flour to 3 large eggs (or about 1/2-2/3 cups water)... by weight, depending heavily on the type of flour you're using, that's about 9oz/255g flour (AP - 00 is lighter, semolina is heavier, but a mix of the two at 250ish g is fine), 6oz/170g egg (please don't weigh your eggs, it's weird) or 4-5oz/115-140g or mL water. Mix it thoroughly, let sit for at least an hour to allow it to become pliable, flour it a little, and run it through a pasta roller.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18937179
People generally use "acidic" to convey a pleasant sourness, and "sour" to mean a harsher unpleasant sourness. Acidic coffee is valued quite highly by some people, but it's a preference thing.
Unpleasant sourness usually comes from underextracting coffee, whereas excessive bitterness comes from overextraction. You can have coffee that has neither of these really and is just sort of sweet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18937179
There are different acids and quality of sourness. Acetic acid is generally garbage because it feels like drinking hot vinegar. Something like malic acid is nice and what I describe in making a “crisp” cup, that give it a light tang to it like a green apple and pair well with fruity notes, just feels tasty and light. I don’t remember all the shit, but probably learned about it in a hoffmeme video. Generally lighter roast can be more acidic. Does it kind of fuck your throat too with the after taste? Sourness/bitterness can also result from fucking up the brew. Then again, some folks I know just can’t tolerate any sourness period, it’s all preferences.

Is overextraction the same as increasing the ratio?

>>18937310
cool

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18937531
No, although ratio can effect it a bit.
Extraction depends primarily on these factors:
>temperature (higher temp = higher extraction)
>how darkly roasted the beans are (darker = higher extraction)
>time (longer = higher extraction)
>grind size (finer = higher extraction)
To a lesser extent it's also effected by the amount of water used, if you use little water it's not going to extract as much, but if you use enough water it extracts more. But that's probably not a factor in most cases unless you're brewing with like an aeropress using the original recipe for it (which has very little water)

Opus has ~40 micron steps. Comandante has 30micron steps, 15 with redclix. Kinu has 10 micron ticks, but its stepless so you can go inbetween steps. JMax has 8.8 micron steps. This just isn't a good product comparatively. You're paying out the ass for that destatic ionizer and the fellow plastic housing. The ode was cool because it opened up 64mm flats in the home market and people didn't have to chase down used superjollys anymore.

ok here are some tips
make the layers thin, hinner than you hink
check every layer before taking it out of he oven, literally made two yares back to back same iime and hickness same batter first one was perfect, second one was raw but it looked perfect, it baked on op but was completely raw at the bottom

buy cheap homey cookies and use those instead, bake them so they brown, it makes 0 difference as you dont really taste the cake crumbs anyways
wai until every layer cools off completely before assembling it, get the cream really cold before whipping, have some extra cream on hand in case you run out by the time you have to decorate the cake
its way sweeter than you expect i to be and its ok if the cream inside is bland, its even better as the cake is exremely flavorful

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18941825
use either american cheese or one of those weird cheese powders they have with premade macaroni and cheese to start, the binding agents involved in those highly processed cheeses helps to smooth things out. Alternatively, try using a bit less flour in the roux and adding the milk/cream in small splashes, thoroughly mixing each time; I'm assuming you're either adding too much flour or not mixing it in slowly enough if it's causing things to seem grainy (or using some kind of insanely cheap flour and not sifting it)

Try the risotto method. Knead 100g of butter with 200g of shredded cheese until well combined then mix/fold into drained, freshly cooked, still-hot pasta, the results of boiling 300g dry. Another option is >>18941974, which is actually my secret to perfect fondue. A the option is to use the black grandma method: best a fucktonne of shredded cheese into a mixture of eggs and evaporated milk, toss with cooked pasta, tip out intoa baking dish, top with more shredded cheese and baked until done

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18941825
There is a good recipe I tried where you boil your macaroni or shells or whatever pasta really in milk. The starch from the pasta helps thicken it (and it also reduces a bit. Add spices to the milk if available like garlic powder, mustard powder, cayenne pepper, black/white pepper whatever and take it off the heat when the pasta is done. You can also add hot sauce. Then add a bunch of shredded cheese (I like to use a combination of sharp cheddar and smoked provolone). Mix well, cover for a few minutes and it's ready to serve. It's very good. You can find the measurements for everything online but that's the basic technique no need to a roux.

>>18938271

Polishing is supposed to make your 2500 edge last a tad longer. Since a knife's edge is basically made of a lot of pointy spikes, a grit past 2000 makes them smaller and thus hold their shape better. They will just be more efficient longer by just using a strop or one of those honing rods, which straighten the spikes that gent bent (but not dulled) after use. Chefs would probably sharpen their knifes around every 2 to 3 weeks but these guys go theough literal tons of vegetables and meats per month and also need something that is razor sharp all the time. Meaning you could easily stay a few months without any sharpening as long as you regulary strop

>>18939972
>1500 will get shaving with skill

this is true. i went so far down the sharpening rabbit hole a few years back that I got into straight razors. if you are going to sharpen a straight razor that you intend to shave with, you should be able to do 20 passes per side on a low grit stone (400-600) and have it cutting hair afterwards. otherwise, you aren't good at sharpening, and you should work on your technique.

of course, quality straight razors don't require a steady hand to hold an angle. you literally just lay one side flat on the stone, do your strokes, and then flip & repeat. the key is to use the same pressure for each side.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18942670
Single bevel? If it is you need to make sure your stone is super flat to work the ura. The front side is either flat or slightly curved. You need to form a burr on the front and then remove it from the other side. After that you use light pressure to refine the edge.

If your knife is double beveled use your fingernail to feel for a gap between the stone and edge. Gently increase the angle until you just can't feel the gap between stone and edge.

2 or 3 fingers on the edge and a firm pinch grip on the handle. Do a few swipes on the stone and recheck your angle using the fingernail test. Checking consistently will help you improve by showing you if you have held the angle consistently.

Eventually you can actually feel if you have the bevel on the stone properly, but that is quite difficult and requires a lot of experience.

>>18942854
You will need to feel and observe to see. Sometimes the blade road has a slight curve to it. Try that fingernail trick I was describing.

The other trick you can try is to observe how the blade undercuts the water on your stone.

You do an edge leading stroke and look to see if water flows over the edge. The blade undercuts the water. This trick also helps show you how sharp your knife is on the stone you're using. As your edge gets closer to the max your stone will give you without any burr the undercut will get more and more pronounced.

>>18942888
You need to use sandpaper backed by something like hard rubber or wood if you're talking about polishing the flats. Do the tightest progression you can and remove the handle if possible. You won't be able to make it look perfect if you can remove the handle.

At the final grit of sandpaper do strokes perfectly straight from handle to tip so the scratch pattern is straight and consistent.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18942899
Oh.. nice a masamoto yani. Pretty nice knives I have a big one.

So sandpaper the flat where the runes are. For the blade road/shinogi you can work a progression of stones. They need to be flat, and you need to be consistent along the entire length of blade.

Once you get up to a high grit you should use finger stones to even out the polish and create good contrast between the hard steel and cladding.

>>18941510
It still improves frozen pizza if you use a pizza stone, you can preheat your pizza stone nice and hot to like 500F, then throw your frozen pizza on it and turn the oven temp down to whatever temp the pizza normally cooks at (so you don't burn your toppings) and then just keep an eye on it and when the cheese is fully melted and looking your preferred color of golden//brown if you prefer things cooked a bit extra.

Takes a bit longer to preheat, but cooks in ~10-12 minutes instead of 18-22.

End result is a much crisper crust underneath and a less floppy pizza.

Holy shit it's identical, you're just skipping the whole point, which is to make sure there's nothing left over on the fucking utensil.

It's a simple concept: a utensil with a lot of surface area means a lot of area that something like honey will stick do. If you're making something (like a sauce) later that needs some liquid sweetener anyway, you can use water to remove all the excess honey from the utensil (or analogous sticky substance for analogous applicable food) because the honey dissolves easily in water. Thus you get virtually zero wasted honey and an easily cleaned utensil. This should not be fucking controversial, yet everybody is hung up on the idea that as soon as water touches something it becomes "dishwater" like a bunch of fucking 5-year-olds.

>>18934421
To those who think they are actually tasting leeched material, whether from metal, plastic, or lack thereof in glass, you can test this yourself at home. If you have a set of 9 or so cups ideally all identical (plastic disposable cups or a glass set), have a friend pour an ounce into 3 cups from each type of container itself in random order, recording which is where on a sheet of paper, then the friend leaves the room with the paper. Then you enter with your own paper, taste in whatever order you like and record which you think is in each cup, putting each back in the same position. Then your helper comes back in and you compare what you got right. By chance alone you should get 3 or 4 correct, so it lends evidence that you are tasting a difference in the original container if you got 1 or none correct, or 6 or more correct.

posts.com:
Inflation is the logical result of increasing the money supply. The increases in prices from inflation are supposed to signal certain behaviors in consumers that would help "right the ship," and bring the economy back into a more stable state. For example, people would start asking for increased pay at their jobs. They would also probably consider what little power they may have left over the process that had just made them poor, and may begin voting for a change in the political administration.

When big corporations hide price increases through "shrinkflation," they are obstructing these processes. The ordinary person is left in ignorance, and since most won't notice at first, the price increases are then "passed on" to the least observant. It bears asking, who are all the parties who benefit from shrinkflation, and why are they benefiting and you are getting screwed?

>>18942141
the way I do any cream of vegetable soup is just grill onions, then add whatever veg you want (in your case mushroom and cauliflower or broccoli would be good, better to leave cabbage for a stew) grill for a bit, then add couple cups of stock or water and bring to a simmer. Let simmer until everything's nice and soft, then let it cool a few minutes before blending it (immersion blender is easiest but you can also add it to a blender, just make sure it's not too hot or it might explode out the blender.)
Then you finally add whatever thickener you're using and heat it back up before serving

Caffeine doesn't wake you up. It simply fills brain receptors that would normally accept the hormone that sends you to sleep. Reminder, it has a halflife of about 8 hours in your system. If you have shitty sleep its because you're preventing your brain and hormones from working normally. Drug. Addicts.

Bro I'm a little bit of a hypocrite; I drink about 3 cups of coffee or tea in the morning because I like the taste, the ritual of preparing the water, french press, pot, cup, and honey or whatever. I definitely do not NEED caffeine as I also drink caffeine free coffee and teas about half the time.

But its more dependent on you personally and how your day goes. I have a caffeine sensitivity and if I made a really strong pot of tea and I finish drinking it at noon, sometimes I just cannot get to sleep until 1 or 2am. if I watch it and I'm careful and make a normal to week pot and finish drinking by 10 while drinking plenty of water throughout the day I'm fine. I also get to sleep a little better if I just don't drink any for the day. That said, caffeine doesn't help anyone sleep better so stopping "too early" is much better than stopping too late. Some people get really pissy because of their caffeine withdrawal symptoms too. Again, thats because they're a drug addict. The approximate halflife is 8 hours, meaning if you stop at 3, its like me drinking a single cup of coffee at 6pm. If you ever noticed your sleep isn't great, its because your brain isn't actually sleeping because of the caffeine. Try stopping at 10am and switch to anything decaf after that. I think even decaf coffee is a diuretic and dehydrates you, I know anything with "energy" like decaf monster or whatever also dehydrates you. Dehydrated brains also don't sleep well.

Just do an experiment for a solid week and try to notice the differences in your mood and sleep after 7 days. Stop caffeine at like 10am and don't drink any on the weekends. worst that happens is the first couple days feel weird but after that your body and brain adjust to less caffeine.

>>18941056
IMO, they can/should be used differently, although if you can’t afford a quality enameled Dutch oven, a regular black iron one can be used for anything. Main limitation of enamel is the inherent fragility of the coating. It’s chemically stable, but physically, though pretty durable, can be damaged. With seasoned iron, the coating is less durable, but can be repaired easily, since it’s just crusty cooking oil.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18941212
For any cookware, smooth is always better. Go check your stainless pots and pans, or your teflon, and tell me how many have the cooking surface of a truck bed liner. Because the seasoning imparts non-stick properties to the metal, it's possible to cook on bumpy pans, but seasoning can be stripped easily if you cook cold meat, like bacon just pulled out of the fridge, or mess up the heat while cooking otherwise to cause food to stick--that goes for bumpy or smooth cast iron. If/when that happens on a bumpy pan, cleaning the stuck-on food is much more difficult than with a smooth pan.

Ideally, you'll build up a thick enough layer of seasoning, regardless of smoothness or bumpiness, but in reality, that rarely happens.

I don't use leeks often in cooking because usually onions, spring onion and shallots are valid substitutes in most recipes, however I do know you're supposed to wash them thoroughly because they're usually very dirty and you don't want soil getting in your good.
How do you wash them without cutting them to the core?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18942180
You should cut your leeks however you need them for your recipe, then put them into a bowl of water and let them soak for a minute or two without stirring, then remove the leeks by scooping them out (don't drain the water like pasta). There's no effective way to wash whole leeks.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>18940226
Yeah, at least here in California all food trucks are required to be "tied" to a sort of a hub where food inspectors regularly check on the conditions of the food trucks. I had a neighbor that worked at one of those "hubs" and she said that they're super adamant about like how clear the water has to be for mopping the floors, and the people that clean the trucks have to get certified to know how to clean properly from top to bottom.

Now, do ALL food trucks follow this rule?

NO. Especially in unincorporated Los Angeles County where it's perfectly legal to just set up a BBQ on any random sidewalk and just start grilling steaks or tacos (those are the best tacos you'll ever have btw.) The real secret is to see how many people are eating at that location. If there's a line, then it's all good, but if you're the only one there then I wouldn't touch it.

(Stay away from the seafood no matter what though).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>18940668
Nope. In 2022 Gov. Newsom signed SB972 into law which although it DOES require that street vendors get permits and follow health codes, it makes it virtually impossible for the enforcers of those health code violations to issue citations or even close down a vendor because it may be perceived as "harassment" which would be a direct violation of that law.

Sacramento is very very good at writing usable loopholes into laws these days.

Here, I had chatgpt sum it up: (but if you want to waste an hour of your day you can look up every letter of the law)

>SB 972 can be difficult for law enforcement to enforce because it prohibits them from criminalizing street vending unless there are health, safety, or welfare concerns. This means that law enforcement officers cannot simply shut down a street vendor's business without just cause.
In order to enforce SB 972, law enforcement officers must be able to identify specific health, safety, or welfare concerns related to a street vendor's business. This can be challenging because many street vendors operate in public spaces and may not have access to facilities like electricity, water, or restrooms. It can also be difficult for law enforcement to distinguish between legitimate health and safety concerns and arbitrary or discriminatory enforcement.
Furthermore, the law provides protections for street vendors from harassment and discrimination by law enforcement officials. This means that law enforcement officers must be careful to avoid any actions that could be seen as targeting street vendors unfairly or disproportionately.
Overall, SB 972 requires law enforcement to exercise discretion and judgment in enforcing the law, which can be challenging in practice.

The officer sees a stand, suspects it's unsafe, snaps photos/video of the unsanitary practices/areas (without absolute minimum disruption of their business) and texts them directly to a health & safety officer or a LE officer trained in this (or rather to the admin who re-sends the photos to whoever is on call.) Depending on the perceived severity, the health officer can give the officer on scene options ranging from ignoring it to shutting down the place temporarily until a qualified health inspector arrives on scene within a couple hours.

This shouldn't be hard to do properly. Beat cops can't and shouldn't be experts in everything, and we've had fucking camera phones for 20 years now.
